{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3205737,"name":null,"username":"Chuck117","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/b4bc9f/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-05-10T01:05:05.496Z","cooked":"

Hello! Our team wanted to do some cad in the off-season using Solidworks and we wanted to use the cad models that exist for swerve drive, however, it is only provided with STEP files or .x_t files so I was wondering if anyone had Solidworks models for the SDS swerve drives? (ideally a non-inverted one but either one would be appreciated)

Those are both interchange formats supported by Solidworks.

if you download the parasolid that is about as close to a solidworks model as you will get

If you ABSOLUTELY want a moving SDS module in Solidworks, you could open the STEP file, break the link (shown below) and save each unique part and make an assembly. It’s a lot of extra work, but you COULD do it.

break link492×684 28.1 KB

For your own sanity, it’s not worth it…

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2023-05-10T04:00:32.747Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":144,"readers_count":143,"score":43.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":436854,"topic_slug":"does-anyone-have-a-solidworks-version-of-the-sds-mk4-swerve-modules","display_username":"Connor McBride","primary_group_name":"FUN","flair_name":"FUN","flair_url":"/uploads/default/original/3X/3/5/3523e759b0af37a7757142a8b2aa79b31f1a47c4.png","flair_bg_color":"","flair_color":"","flair_group_id":60,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/c/9/c96baf263710ca372253b26f20741ed8a717c455.png","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":25281,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Powered by Flavor Blasted Goldfish"},"post_url":"/t/does-anyone-have-a-solidworks-version-of-the-sds-mk4-swerve-modules/436854/5","custom_user_title":"Powered by Flavor Blasted Goldfish","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3205807,"name":"Clayton Ramsey","username":"ClayTownR","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/claytownr/{size}/158381_2.png","created_at":"2023-05-10T04:19:18.869Z","cooked":"

I believe you don’t even need to save out the parts from the original file - the parts can be stored inside the assembly file for convenience.

If you want to import the model, I recommend using the Parasolid (.x_t) format in SOLIDWORKS since SOLIDWORKS uses the Parasolid kernel and will have an easier time importing it.
